head.title: Aug. 14-20: Bleak Education Report; Decades After Sputnik Science Education Still Lags

hedline.hl1: Aug. 14-20: Bleak Education Report; Decades After Sputnik Science Education Still Lags

block.p: If the graphs the Department of Education submitted last week with its latest report card on student achievement levels were EKG results, they would describe a patient who was dead. There was some sign of life in math and science. But reading and writing showed barely a ripple of improvement over 20 years.

Back in 1957, when Sputnik was launched, the fervor for meeting the Soviet challenge generated an explosion of science training and research. But a decade after the 1983 report "A Nation at Risk" alerted America to broad failures in education, the news is not much better.

If the graphs the Department of Education submitted last week with its latest report card on student achievement levels were EKG results, they would describe a patient who was dead. There was some sign of life in math and science. But reading and writing showed barely a ripple of improvement over 20 years.

Back in 1957, when Sputnik was launched, the fervor for meeting the Soviet challenge generated an explosion of science training and research. But a decade after the 1983 report "A Nation at Risk" alerted America to broad failures in education, the news is not much better.

Perhaps the most troubling statistics involve those who have already made their way through the school system. According to the report, only 2 percent of 11th graders can write effectively with "supportive details and discussion" though they all could "respond to tasks in abbreviated, disjointed, or unclear ways."

If one segment of the department's own report was any indication, the students were in good company. On page 227, a student writing sample described a haunted house: "Man builds stange house to scare ghosts. . . . for instince there are staires that go nowhere, doors that go nowhere and hallways that go nowhere."

Unfortunately, the sample itself went nowhere. Not only did the text fail to explain what the example was supposed to show, it also neglected to mention an important detail -- how old the student was. CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD
